Hello Colin,
    I added a Novelty fitness system to the SharpNeat 2D Bipe=
dal Walker with some interesting results. It appeared to evolve better walk=
ers faster than than the traditional fitness function with a much smaller p=
opulation size (I used 150 down from the default 4000). However I was still=
 unable to evolve a natural "human" looking walk under either the novelty o=
r the traditional fitness function.

    Watching the best found solutions =
reminded me of watching someone trying to walk underwater, or bounce-walkin=
g on the moon which leads me to this question: The model has several consta=
nts for friction, density and uses a default "SetMassFromShapes" function f=
or the various walker body parts.  Is it reasonable to add extra outputs to=
 Neat to find optimal values for these various constants, before running th=
e actual walking simulation?

I have posted the Novelty search source code =
in an attachment over on the SharpNeat forum, with some notes:

https://gro=
ups.google.com/forum/?hl=3Den&fromgroups#!forum/sharpneat

--
Keith

--- In=
 neat@yahoogroups.com, Colin Green <colin.green1@...> wrote:
>
> http://www=
.youtube.com/watch?v=3DKMy2zRN4d38
> 
> I hope to check the code into SVN s=
oon, there are also a few fixes
> that have been submitted to the SVN repos=
itory recently, some fairly
> significant, e.g. the prey capture domain was=
 effectively completely
> broken (it works a lot better now!). Will aim to =
make package up a new
> SharpNEAT release 7zip soon.
> 
> Regarding the wal=
ker, any advice on improving the fitness function?
> This one has stop cond=
itions for when one or both of the feet are too
> high, the torso height go=
es below a threshold or any of the the joint
> angles go beyond 90 degrees.=
 Ideally I'd like to avoid these and make
> it more open ended (and punish =
for applied torque to get efficient
> walkers) but the reality was that tha=
t didn't seem to work very well.
> 
> Regards,
> 
> Colin
